captions.text:
MIKE MUSTO: Back in the early
1950s, Chevrolet released a

car that changed the
way Americans
view open road motoring.

It was a small two
seat roadster.

And even though it wasn't very
fast, that didn't stop it from

evolving into one of America's
premier sports cars.

Now of course I'm talking about
the Chevrolet Corvette,
a car that we know and love.

However, on this episode of Big
Muscle, we're not going to
focus on that.

You see today we're going to
focus on the competition.

This is a 1955 Ford Thunderbird,
a car that was

built as a direct competitor
to the Corvette.

Where the Corvette was marketed
to a more youthful

audience, the Thunderbird was
marketed as more of a personal
luxury statement.

A car for the executive,
if you will.

Now, we've also been fortunate
enough to meet the owner, a
man by the name of Leni Faas.

And he's given us the keys
to this thing today.

So sit back, relax, and enjoy
this episode of Big Muscle as

we roll on through,
T-Bird style.
[CAR ENGINE]
[MUSIC PLAYING]
[TIRES SCREECHING]

MIKE MUSTO: This particular
Thunderbird comes from a

family with a long raising
history behind it, which may

help explain why the car was
built with such extreme
modifications in mind.

LENI FAAS: This car's been in
the family since brand new.

Vern Houle was the original
owner of the car.

He worked back in 1955
with Bill Stroppe.

They were fabricating all of
the cars for Ford Motor

Company for the Mexican
road race.

Vern bought this car under the
employee program where he got
the discount for the car.

He brought it in to Stroppe's
facility in Long Beach and was
modifying it just for himself.

Shortly thereafter, Ford began
to pull out of that race which

then left Bill Stroppe
with not much to do.

And he decided to close
the facility.

Vern didn't have really any
place to go, so my grandfather

had gone by and visited the car
many times while it was at
Stroppe's facility.

And he ended up buying the car
from Vern, and hired Vern.

Brought him over to [INAUDIBLE],
which is a

manufacturing plant they had
nearby in South Gate.

He put them in the back, in
the tool room, and had him

finish the car over the
next few years.
[CAR ENGINE]

MIKE MUSTO: We're going to
start this episode with a
drinking game.

Now obviously we're not going
to intermingle it with the

road test, but here's
the deal.
See this car is set up with two
inches of ground clearance.
Two.

It has a skin plate on it
that's about that thick.

So every time you hear
this car bottom
out, we got to drink.
Well, you've got to drink.
I've got to drive.
And JF, you can drink milk.
[CAR ENGINE REVVING]
[CAR ENGINE]

MIKE MUSTO: So you may have
noticed that I'm a little
squat down in this thing.

You see, this car's got a
roof line that's been
chopped four inches.

And for guys like me, that are
6' 4" and about 240 pounds,

this isn't the most
ideal ride.

I mean I'm kind of jammed
in this thing.

Now, of course, I'll
be honest.
I look pretty bad ass.
I mean, think about it.

I'm cruising around in a '55
T-Bird, all blacked out,

that's got some touches that
are pretty amazing.

Now, they're especially amazing
when you consider that
this car was built in 1968.

Now obviously it's a '55, but
the changes to the body were
all done in '68.

The chopped roof line, or the
chopped windshield, the

fenders were rolled in, the
doors were smooth and rolled.

I mean, there were so many
little nuances on this car

that make it stand out amongst
any other '55 T-bird you're
ever going to see.
[CAR ENGINE]

LENI FAAS: Vern did all of the
cosmetic work that you see
done to this car right here.

They stripped everything
out of this car.
There is no heater box.

They gutted everything
out of the doors.
They threw away the top.

They rolled everything
on the body.
They dropped in a 428--

one of the motors from Ford,
for the Mexican rallies--

and set the motor down in the
frame, cut out the firewall,

relocated it 18 inches
further back.
And of course the body work--

the fenders have been
cut and rolled back.

They basically took anything
that had any weight, or really

no function, it was removed
from the car.

MIKE MUSTO: At first glance,
the T-Bird's interior looks
relatively stock.

But upon closer inspection
you'll notice that everything,

except the gauges, have
been modified in
order to save weight.

Even the custom chassis's been
lightened, rounding out the

car's total weight to about
2,500 pounds, or about the
same as a Mazda Miata.

This weight loss means you'll
also be able to get the most

out of the T-Bird's 425
horsepower, 428 big block.
[CAR ENGINE]

MIKE MUSTO: So how does
this thing drive?

Well, right from the get-go,
like I said-- because the car
is so low--
it's difficult.

I mean, we're constantly
scanning the road for
imperfections.

If the road has a rut, we
actually have to ride on the

high side of the rut so
as not to bottom out.
Now while all this--
[SCRAPE]
ew, like that, drink--
now while all of this [SCRAPE]

lends to an unbelievable
[SCRAPE]
looking car--

all right, you guys are
going to be [BLEEP]

faced in, I don't know,
20 minutes.

I mean, I'm about 240 pounds,
Thad's about the
same, we're big guys.

So with almost 500 pounds in
this thing, that compresses

the suspension just enough to
make us hit everything.

I have to concentrate,
so right now--
[SCRAPE]
ah, drink.
Keep drinking.
You know what?
Just [SCRAPE]

get a bottle of vodka, open
it up, and just start
pounding right now.

Because I'll be amazed if
there's any bottom of the car

left by the time that
we're actually done.
[SCRAPE] [SCRAPE] [SCRAPE].
Oh my god, mother in heaven!
It's difficult.

This is actually a difficult
car to review.

Because when you look at this
thing, all you want to do is

you want to get in, and you want
to put your foot down,

and you want to go
buck wild fast.

But it's hard to do because
the car does sit so low.
[SCRAPE]
[SCRAPE]
[SCRAPE].

I don't even know how
that's possible.
We're going six.

All right, so after a day of
shooting on back roads, we

finally decided to take this car
where I think it's going

to be fantastic, and that's
actually out on the open road.

Now let's get on and see
what this thing does.
Ah, there we go.
OK.

Now we've got a good
understanding about this car.

See, on the back roads we
really couldn't explore
anything with this car.
But right here--
cruising about 65, 70--

this is where this
car wants to be.

So how does the car drive
on the open road?

The steering is actually
pretty good.

It's tight, it's got a Mustang
II steering rack in it and it

makes the steering inputs
pretty precise.

Leni's running two
15s up front.
Not a lot of tire up here.

But the cool part is you'd never
know it by the way the
car is set up.
It doesn't look it.

It looks like it's running like
a 265 or 275 series tire.

The other part is like I said--
with the B&M Ratchet--

I mean we're rolling and you
roll into it, and you can feel
the [BLEEP]
go baby.

I mean, I don't know if this
speedometer's accurate.

But if it is, we could
go to jail really
quick in this thing.
The tranny--

it's a reverse valve body,
and it shifts good.

Although it's set up really
for the streets.

So the first, to second, to
third shifts are really fast.

It's boom, boom, boom, just
to get you rolling.

I mean it is nice that I can
click it back, drop it down,

and if I want to get
some speed in it, I
could totally do that.

So now we're taking an
exit ramp, right?
You can throw the car in.
It sticks really, really nice.
Not a lot of drama.

Same thing, roll on the
throttle, throw the car into
the corner.

Even with the small series
tires, it behaves really well.
It's really compliant.
It feels good.

And we had to take it out here,
because I just couldn't

give you an honest back road
assessment of this thing.
I just couldn't do it.

Now, however, I can
tell you flat out.
I'm digging this thing.

Now, granted, I think what I
might do if this was mine is

maybe put an air ride suspension
in it so I could
adjust the height at will.

This way if you're going over
a speed bump or you're going

into a parking lot you
could get in and out.

But like I said, this
isn't my car.

This is Leni's car,
and he loves it.
So hell, we love it too.

LENI FAAS: We have had
ridiculous offers on this car.

My cousin had a number
of them.

My cousin got the car
from my brother.

So my cousin, Jerry, took
the car and did
the upgrades to it.

And then the car was being asked
to go into a few shows
and won a number of shows.

And during those shows my cousin
was offered $100,000,
plus your pick of a guy's--
one of his Ferraris.
All kinds of crazy things.

I was actually at a coffee shop
one morning with my kids

and received a phone call from
a car broker who had been
trying to track it down.

And on the telephone
he went as high as
$225,000 for the car.

And the car's really
not for sale.
I couldn't sell it.

I don't need the money, and my
nephew, Casey, would probably

have me killed if I got
rid of this vehicle.

MIKE MUSTO: So today we spent
the day with Leni Faas and his
wicked 1955 Thunderbird.

And it's taught me a couple of
things about true hot rodding.

Now, Leni described
this car the best.

He said this car was a bar
hopper, and you know what?
It is.

This car would be the equivalent
of one of the

nicest Harleys you've
ever seen.

You don't want to take it on a
200-mile road trip, but to get

around town and to show off,
I can't think of a better
vehicle to be in.
We really hope you liked it.

We're glad you came along
today, and we'd
like to thank Leni.

And if you've got a car that you
want to see on Big Muscle,

drop us a line at
drivebigmuscle@gmail.com, and
we'll get right back to you.

So we hope you enjoyed
this episode.
Take care.
[CHUCKLES]
Yeah, that's right.
THAD: That's right, yo.
MIKE MUSTO: That's right, yo.
How are you doing?
What's going on?
OK.

I feel like I should be
cruising Miami Beach.
What's up, ladies?
How are you?
FEMALE SPEAKER: Nice car.
MIKE MUSTO: Thank you.
That lady had a mustache.
It was bigger than mine.
Hey, this is what happens.

Get the guy with the
pink scooter.
[SCOOTER ENGINE]
MIKE MUSTO: Safety first.

Because the pink scooter
isn't manly enough.
You've got to get the vest.

That says, I live in
San Francisco.

title: 1955 Ford Thunderbird: Back in Black -- /BIG MUSCLE

comments.text:
This thing looks awesome. The only thing that I would change would be the 
wheels they look a little late 80's and 90's to me﻿
comments.author: Tyler Freeland

comments.text:
People stop complaining about the power. There comes a time and a place 
where the power is not needed. When the car looks that good, all one cares 
about is riding in style and not riding fast.﻿
comments.author: TheHm3

comments.text:
I usually like this kind of restomod, but this is sacrilege. The 1955 
Thunderbird is a thing of beauty, the ultimate classic american car...they 
should be kept as shining examples of the glory days for America, the 50's. 
Not as a shining example of the bullshit state of the USA in the present 
day...﻿
comments.author: Snakebloke

comments.text: +ryan bycroft Fair enough :) I can go with that.
comments.author: Snakebloke

comments.text: +Snakebloke as long as there is one original specimen the rest r fair game
comments.author: ryan bycroft

comments.text: i just had an orgasm...fucking awesome﻿
comments.author: Kirill Bezzubkine

comments.text:
So, let me get this straight. If I toss a crate 428 in my stock 55 T-bird, 
shed some weight and modernize the suspension and it goes from $20,000 to 
$250,000!? I need to find a drive train...﻿
comments.author: redneckhippiefreak

comments.text:
This is like down the street from me on 680! Where exactly are those back 
roads you guys were on?﻿

comments.text: Fucking stupid steering wheel.﻿

who cares about engine size and power. we run out of oil soon. so wtf do 
you do with 1000 hp then.hmmm﻿
comments.author: M Riippa

comments.text: +will M yeah. on you
comments.author: M Riippa

comments.text: were you dropped as a child?
comments.author: will M

comments.text: cars models from the 50's and 60's are the best﻿
comments.author: freeeeeman952

comments.text: why?﻿
comments.author: Darril Stroecker

comments.text: Why make the car look so modern, sort of ruins the style.﻿
comments.author: Kinesis17

comments.text:
Hahaha!! You gotta get the vest because the pink scooter just isn't manly 
enough.. ﻿
comments.author: scheethoofd

comments.text: that was painful to watch.﻿
comments.author: harrier331

comments.text:
Only 425hp? What?
My race car is from 1955 as well... and it makes 330hp.
from an engine that is less than half the size of this one.
so from an extra 3.6 litres, they got a grand total of 95 tyre shredding 
horses. How?﻿
comments.author: Foxtrot Oscar

comments.text:
"Smalur injin maek moar paoer? Fukin kommies." - Rednecks upon discovering 
a 2.5 liter 2JZ can make the same, if not more power than their 500 cu in.+ 
shitboxes.
comments.author: Get Rekt

comments.text:
+Bob Marley Thanks man, it's nice to come across someone who actually 
understands logic and reason. Worryingly rare in these parts.
When I get round to it I'll do a full shoot of everything in one go. Until 
then, there's not a lot I can do unfortunately.
comments.author: Foxtrot Oscar

comments.text:
+Foxtrot Oscar I dont see why people got so mad with your comment. Yea the 
first comment you seemed like another youtube douche, but then you backed 
up your reasoning with what I thought was a good argument. Why have an 
engine built for big power and not use it when you can have a cheaper more 
efficient engine. People take criticism to hard... Your cars sound nice man 
if you do get that camera film them right away!
comments.author: Bob Marley

comments.text:
+devilskullBEL My Nokia 3410 doesn't have a camera. But it is 
indestructible, which is why I have one. It won't break when it flies 
across the dash of my Landy, out the window, down a cliff and into a bog.

My life? A camera is life? No, those cars are my life. Everything I have 
goes into them, because everything I enjoy doing I can do with them. Any 
left over goes into the big saving pot, and is spent on a project car. 
That's my hobby, doing up cars.
Once it's done up, I drive it, sell it for profit (I'm getting pretty good 
at spotting money makers) and go down the pub.

Laugh if you want but I like my life in the beautiful county of Cornwall in 
my 100+ year old house with my idiotic collection of old cars. And Dog.

If I ever *need* money, I've got a shit load of parts, old shells, panels, 
engines, drivelines, suspension setups and chassis's that I can sell. 
Failing that, one of the complete cars..  But it's never come to that 
because I'm careful how I spend.
comments.author: Foxtrot Oscar

comments.text:
All discussions aside (whether you're right or wrong).

Seems like you have a big mouth but nothing to back you up.

If you really are that poor that you can't buy anything that can film and 
connect to your pc (my 5 year old smartphone can do that in 720p HD while 
it only cost me €200 back then), then it might be time for you to get rid 
of your car and put your money in your life.
comments.author: devilskullBEL

comments.text:
+rebernard82 Place yourself in my shoes. You've built a very, very stupid 
(but fun) car for very little money by pulling favours, working for free 
and doing almost all of it yourself.
I haven't got much money, so spending £200 on a Go Pro or whatever is out 
of the question. That's a track day, or a complete fluid swap or money 
towards this years insurance bill...
When you're working to a budget, you have to prioritise.
The few videos I have of it are on cassette tape (my current camera is 
pretty ancient) and the only digital ones are copyright. Sorry.
I have sound clips, but I need to get them re-formatted to actually work.

Miles per Hour.
Heck the original D types did 170-180mph, I wouldn't make one *slower!*
comments.author: Foxtrot Oscar

comments.text:
+Foxtrot Oscar sooo, you ask me to remember the point I made in the first 
place?  torque and horsepower are different. duh.  Why not post a video of 
the race car you keep bragging about doing that 200...unless you are 
measuring that speed in kph, that wouldn't be very exciting.
comments.author: rebernard82

comments.text:
+rebernard82 Here's an important thing to remember. Torque is force. Power 
is force over time.
Force moves mass, the time it takes is dictated by the power. X torque will 
move up to X mass. X torque moving half that moves it just as fast. Once 
you have enough torque to shift the mass (plus other resistances) then it's 
all power baby.

Then again, it's a 3.4 litre straight six, so it's got guts where it 
matters. I can tow a trailer with it, and it'll hit 200, which is a *lot* 
of force.
comments.author: Foxtrot Oscar

comments.text:
here an important thing to consider... Torque. yeah foxtrot, your old race 
car might have that horsepower number, but so do many diesel pickup trucks. 
probably not moving heavy objects with that screaming race engine of yours.
comments.author: rebernard82

comments.text:
+devilskullBEL In an endurance test, mine would win. I've had 4 years of 
endurance races, day races, track days and road use out of it, running hard 
for up to 24 hours straight. Its, built like a brick shithouse that engine. 
Pushrods are notorious for being less stable when subject to extended high 
RPM use. 
Dont forget, D types were designed to run the 24 hours of Le Mans, probabky 
the harshest race for engines there is, or was, thanks to the flat out 
Mulsanne straight, the longest in racing, and the flat out front straight 
too. 

Loads of torque across the whole rev range is bad. You dont need it all at 
the bottom end at all, and it makes the engine much harder to control 
precisely out of corners. You want progressive power.
comments.author: Foxtrot Oscar

comments.text:
+Foxtrot Oscar If put to an endurance test, this engine will last WAY 
longer than yours, simply because it has a very big reserve, whereas yours 
is closer to it's limits if used like you make it sound you use it.

This car most likely has loads of torque in any rpm-range too.
comments.author: devilskullBEL

comments.text:
425 hp is plenty, yes. So a 4.5 litre engine is plenty too. You don't need 
600 hp, so you don't need a 7 litre engine either.
I didn't really mention the amount of low...

You *should* care about the engine, it's the heart and soul of the vehicle 
and to a great extent defines its character.
comments.author: Foxtrot Oscar

comments.text:
Why would you need/want more? 425 is more than enough + when driving around 
that low, you can't use 1/4th of that horsepower.

I've driven 3 cars as low as that and even lower (half an inch ground 
clearance).
You don't get the fun from the speed, you get it from the 'achievement' of 
getting somewhere, from the peoples looks, from the swearing each time you 
pray for magic powers when you have to undo a bolt underneath to replace 
something that completely scraped off.

Engine is something you couldn't care any less of, you just service and 
maintain it.
comments.author: devilskullBEL

comments.text:
+turtle2448thomas Oh they're not perfect, believe me. If they were, the D 
type would start cold first time, the XJ wouldn't need body attention, the 
E type would have correct trim and seats and the S13 would be straight 
rather than slightly wiggly where it's been smacked about. Oh, and the Land 
Rover wouldn't smell of wet dog.

I can find beauty, however there is no beauty in an engine that  not only 
sounds a bit naff, is built to a very ugly design (from an engineers point 
of view) and fails to make anywhere near the amount of power that one would 
expect from a piston engine of its size and application.
The car looks fine, bar the over-large wheels which don't suit the age of 
the body at all, but that's opinion. The fact is, the engine is a fraction 
of what it should be a that's just not cool.
comments.author: Foxtrot Oscar

comments.text:
+Foxtrot Oscar No one gives half a shit about your "perfect" cars that you 
keep bragging about. We are all car guys and love beauty like the car 
shown. If you can't find beauty in a car someone built with their own two 
hands then what the hell are you doing here?
comments.author: turtle2448thomas

comments.text:
+turtle2448thomas Why? It's a valid point. If this is meant to be a 
performance vehicle... why does it not actually deliver the performance 
that its spec sheet would suggest?
By that, I mean 7.01 litres should be making around 600hp. To be performing 
equally to my (55 year old) engine, it'd need to be making 680hp. That's 
the whole reason for having a 7 litre engine, surely, to make power?
comments.author: Foxtrot Oscar

comments.text: Just. Shut. Up.
comments.author: turtle2448thomas

comments.text: This thing is insane. :) 2500lbs? 400+ horsepower Nice.﻿
comments.author: Danny Giroux

comments.text: Now that's how you do a restomod. Nothing over the top, nice simple lines.﻿
comments.author: Emerson Lake

comments.text: The same weight as a mazda miata?? Omggggg﻿
comments.author: Sebastian Moreno

comments.text:
I really appreciate the craftsmanship and engineering that went into the 
car. It's the nicest looking custom two seater T-Bird that I've ever seen. 
I'm not a big fan of these cars. This one is one that I would actually 
consider putting in my garage. It looks very understated from a distance. 
Yet when you get closer, you see all the details. Little subtleties go a 
long way on cars. But that's just my opinion.﻿

That ride height is ridiculous. I had stock height on my 95 Camaro and 
punched through the oil pan of a fresh 396 SBC, pissed me off so bad. But I 
knew it was busted and didn't hurt the motor. A tow and coil spacers later 
and she'll ride over any big bump smoothly.﻿

comments.author: rex redgeback

comments.text: I'm not sure he was joking about his nephew having him killed.
comments.author: highlands

comments.text:
And no one would care, cos no matter how fast you made it go, it can never 
be cool.
comments.author: CosmoxYRik

comments.text: I doubt there is one bolt, or piece of iron from 1955 on that 'bird....!
comments.author: hankgs

comments.text:
This is not a 1955 Ford Thunderbird. I know there are some people that are 
interested in modifying cars, but really. A '55 T-bird exists today to 
preserve a period in automotive history that represents our artistic mind 
at work, and doing something like this to one is like disgracing it's 
heritage in a way. It honestly doesn't look good like this. What happened 
to the white-walls, hubcaps, chrome trim, and the porthole? Those were 
icons of the 50's, and on this car, it's been destroyed.
comments.author: ClassicNintendoShow

comments.text:
Also Aki Ami Masen, you are clearly not a real car person because you dont 
respect other car guys, if you did your 4 useless comments would have been 
respectful
comments.author: Patrick Pelletier

comments.text:
Aki Ami Masen shut the fuck up, they built it the way THEY WANTED because 
its THEIR CAR. Listen to what Mike says and once again il tell you, shut 
the fuck up. Also w dont all like the same cars you fucking idiot
comments.author: Patrick Pelletier

comments.author: Clint Estwood

comments.text:
That's not true. It's up to the owner to personalize it/upgrade it to make 
it special and stand out. I used to have a stock 2005 V6 Mustang. Totally 
plain jane. Now, It has a 5.4l V8, black racing stripes, gloss black & 
chrome bullitt rims, custom interior, long tube headers, X-pipe bassannii 
exhaust, hot rod cams, etc etc. It's all about the people. It up to them to 
personalize it and thats why cars these days have so much room to modify 
them.

comments.text:
I love the car, very tastefully done! Solution for the suspension: A 
reactive suspension system would allow feedback to a baseline pressure 
point in a microprocessor. It would react to the overburdon of weight 
inside the car w/ 2 big boys or when pushing thru the corners. That'd cause 
body roll and compress the shocks so, you could also install a hidden 
button that allows the driver to change the baseline pressure point in the 
processor, to allow a more aggressive driving. Nice video, Thanks!
